results.headline: Girl Meets Ape, and Complications Ensue

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ugly Truth

results.summary_short: “The Ugly Truth” is a cynical, clumsy, aptly titled attempt to cross the female-oriented romantic comedy with the male-oriented gross-out comedy.

results.headline: Physician, Drug Thyself: Psychiatrist in Hollywood

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shrink

results.summary_short: Like smog settling over Los Angeles, a creeping sense of anomie haunts the Hollywood power players and parasites sidling nervously through “Shrink.”

results.headline: Perusing the Homoerotic Playbook

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sabor Tropical

results.summary_short: An aggressively hetero American male is seduced by a hot Colombian pickpocket in “Sabor Tropical.”

results.headline: Beneath the Veil of the Immigrant Dream

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paraiso Travel

results.summary_short: The tangled issue of illegal immigration gives “Paraíso Travel” its motivation, but thoughtful storytelling and committed performances give the movie its heart.

results.headline: New Kid in the House, Clearly Up to Something

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Orphan

results.summary_short: Actors have to eat like the rest of us, but you still have to wonder how Vera Farmiga and Peter Sarsgaard ended up wading through “Orphan” and not laughing.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of G-Force

results.summary_short: “G-Force” manages to be fairly entertaining in that exhausting, rackety, late-summer-kiddie-movie way.

results.summary_short: “California Company Town” meditates on the fate of communities forged by the demands of industry, and then abandoned when those needs changed.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Answer Man

results.summary_short: “The Answer Man” is a movie about the softening up of a curmudgeon: a familiar premise and not necessarily a terrible one.

results.summary_short: “A Woman in Berlin,” is a sprawling, difficult, powerful film.

results.summary_short: In Boaz Yakin’s film “Death in Love,” Holocaust scars span generations.

results.summary_short: “The Way We Get By” is unfailingly modest and profoundly humane.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Off Jackson Avenue

results.summary_short: “Off Jackson Avenue,” which might have been called “Last Exit to Queens,” is not the first movie to follow a victim of sex trafficking into a living nightmare.

results.summary_short: “Homecoming” is coldly efficient for what it is. But what it is is trash.

results.summary_short: Two things keep “Heart of Stone” from being like every other documentary about a dedicated principal who tries to turn a failed urban high school around.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of (500) Days of Summer

results.summary_short: “(500) Days of Summer” finds just the right scale and tone, neither trivializing nor melodramatically overstating the delicate feelings it explores.

results.summary_short: “The Age of Stupid” is a frightening jeremiad about the effects of climate change.

results.summary_short: “Somers Town” is an agreeable if slight, vaguely sketched character study times two.
